texts.definition: Games where there is only one player in a game instance.
description: The player in [Single-Player Games](single-player-games) is in a conflict situation with the game system. It is possible, and sometimes even desirable, to analyze these games in such a way that conflict with the game system is framed as a conflict situation in [Multiplayer Games](multiplayer-games). This personification of the game system often helps to clear the goal structures and the motivations for the conflict situation.
examples: The vast majority of computer games are [Single-Player Games](single-player-games) where the player is competing against or in conflict with the game system.

Puzzles of any kind can be classified as [Single-Player Games](single-player-games) although they are a borderline case between games and game-like activities, because they do not typically have the conflict situations common to games in general.
usage: The amount of the possible [Social Interaction](social-interaction) can be increased by using, for example, [Score](score) to measure the performance of the player. This allows players to compare their performances to one other and to use "Highscore Lists" to create simple [Meta Games](meta-games) with multiple players. A more refined method is to have [Ghosts](ghosts) in the game where players can directly compare their performance between each other during the play.

The goals and conflicts, as previously noted, can even in [Single-Player Games](single-player-games) be structured in similar fashion as in [Multiplayer Games](multiplayer-games). For example, by analyzing "Pac-Man" as a game between the Pac-Man and the ghosts reveals somewhat surprising similarities with "Tag", including the [Role Reversals](role-reversal). Even "Tetris" can be thought of as a conflict between the (computer controlled) player who is trying to fill the screen and the player who is trying to keep the screen clear. The [Rewards](rewards) and [Penalties](penalties) in [Single-Player Games](single-player-games) are best crafted as [Individual Rewards](individual-rewards) and [Individual Penalties](individual-penalties).

[Single-Player Games](single-player-games) are free to have player specific modulations of game time, such as [Game Pauses](game-pauses) and [Cut Scenes](cut-scenes). Other game state manipulations, which are outside the game itself, are trivially possible in [Single-Player Games](single-player-games). [Reversability](reversability) with [Save-Load Cycles](save-load-cycles) is simple, as all that is required is to store the game state for later use.

The ways to modulate [Right Level of Difficulty](right-levelof-difficulty) can be done somewhat differently in [Single-Player Games](single-player-games) compared to [Multiplayer Games](multiplayer-games). First, by having players complete [Levels](levels), the game designers can control what sort of challenges the players should meet. Second, it is easier to control what information the player has that can be used to give a player [Limited Planning Ability](limited-planning-ability).
consequences: [Single-Player Games](single-player-games) cannot have [Social Interaction](social-interaction) between the players of the same game instance, but if the game is played in a social situation, such as an arcade machine in a pub, there is a possibility for spontaneous [Social Interaction](social-interaction) with the player and the [Spectators](spectators). Even though the potential players are not sharing the game instance, they do share the [Alternative Reality](alternative-reality) provided by the game, and this can, in games with [Narrative Structures](narrative-structures) and applications of [Imperfect Information](imperfect-information), especially [Easter Eggs](easter-eggs) and [Exploration](exploration), lead to another kind of [Social Interaction](social-interaction) around the game where the players share their experiences and sometimes help each other solve difficult problems and progress in the game.
